metadata.title: Convert Gradians to Degrees – Angle Converter
metadata.description: Convert angles from Gradians (grad) to Degrees, useful for interpreting surveying measurements.

introduction: This converter transforms gradians to familiar degrees for angle interpretation.
European surveyors may use gradians; converting to degrees enables worldwide communication.
This converter uses the relationship where 100 gradians equals 90 degrees.
methodology: 90° = 100 grad. To convert gradians to degrees, multiply by 0.9 (or 9/10).
Gradians offer decimal precision but degrees remain universally recognized.
Understanding gradian-to-degree conversion is useful for international surveying work.
This converter provides precise angle conversion for surveying communication.

faqs.question: How do I convert gradians to degrees?
Is the conversion 1 grad = 0.9°?
faqs.answer: Yes. 1 grad = 0.9° exactly. So multiply gradians by 0.9 for degrees.

faqs.question: Why use gradians at all?
faqs.answer: 400-part circle is decimal-friendly. 100 grad per quadrant. Useful for calculations.

faqs.question: Are gradians used in modern surveying?
faqs.answer: Declining. Degrees remain most common. Some European instruments still use gradians.

faqs.question: What's a decimal minute in gradians?
faqs.answer: Gradians often given as decimals (50.25 grad). No subdivisions like degree minutes/seconds.

faqs.question: Can I use gradians with a standard protractor?
faqs.answer: Most protractors show degrees. Gradian protractors exist but are uncommon.

faqs.question: How do mils relate to gradians?
faqs.answer: Military mils: 6,400 per circle. Gradians: 400 per circle. Both offer precision vs degrees.

faqs.question: Should I learn gradians?
faqs.answer: Only if you work in European surveying. Otherwise, focus on degrees and radians.

glossary.definition: Angle unit with 400 per full circle. Also called gon or grade.
Angle unit with 360 per full circle. Most common system.
Instrument measuring angles. May display degrees or gradians.
Angle measured in horizontal plane during surveying.
